column4: I hate shopping and I hate the cold so finding the underground city was a relief. I was able to sit whilst the others did their shopping. It was lovely and warm. What a great idea.

We visited Montreal the day following a snow storm, so walking was much more pleasant underground. The streets above ground were difficult to navigate due to the snow, and it was very cold. Underground has so many shops and restaurants, and it's a great place for people watching.
That is a different world under the city's ground. Very lively and happy place. One needs a couple of days to explore it.
Lots of places to eat and shop. Metro stations close by. Only warning is that instead of braving the cold, you will have to walk a lot more.
During a recent snowstorm (no surprise), I spent three hours exploring the maze. Fascinating. In the winter there's also an incredible public art walking tour w/ more than 50 installations. Fun!
We started at Eaton Centre and walked all the way to our hotel. The shops are nothing spectacular, standard to any other mall in American. I thought there would be more stores unique to Canada.
Very cool concept! Love how you can get out of the cold and explore montreals underground shopping centres. Many different malls to choose from. Loved it!

While the main part of the underground city is easily accessible from ground level on Sainte Catherine Street, you can also access it from many block away through a maze of underground tunnel walkways, but it is also easy to get lost or disoriented! Enter from Sainte Catherine's Street and note the stores closest to your entrance and you will...

It makes complete sense. Montreal can be really cold, and snowy in the winter. And the winter can last a long time in Canada. So, why not have the malls interconnected, and other businesses too? While you're at it, connect different parts of the city so you can travel distances while staying warm and dry! Brilliant! There are no down...

Regardless of the weather outside, get yourself underground and wander the shops. There are thousands of them adjoined from several city blocks above and are easy to navigate. There is something for everyone, boundless shops with eager shop keepers ready to serve you. A great way to get in tune with an awesome city and its people.

Not sure what the sadness is about when it comes to this place. It's madebfor ppl that love to Shop as well as getting out of whatever weather is outside. For ppl saying they have last year's clothing so I'm guess old navy is selling pass year clothes huh. There's name brand appeals as well as small boutiques try it...
you may enjoy lot of shopping with various counters having delicacies from all over the world. it connects 4 metro stations and is huge.

First, "Underground City" is an exaggeration. It really is a cluster of buildings surrounding a very large area connected in a tortuous way by underground walkways.While some signs are clear, others are misleading, inconsistent or downright non-existent. Even with the help of a map from the hotel, I had to stop twice to ask for directions. I had to...

The Reso (Network) has its own character, and while it could be considered as nothing but a number of concrete tunnels going from mid-town to out-skirt of old Montreal, I that visitors should experience it at leat once, and if it is cold or rainy day, it would be an option if you want to remain warm and dry!

When visiting Montreal I love to go shopping in the underground city. You don't have to worry about the weather and there are an array of shops for different taste and price range. While visiting we had the chance to see the Barbie Expo which was amazing to see.
Visited the Underground City numerous times during our three day stay in Downtown. An interesting shopping experinence to say the least - and a convenient one especially in Winter.

Luckily for me I had two weeks in Montreal to explore the maze of underground spaces that is the underground city. I had a map, I occasionally found maps on the walls that said you are here, however I was never confident that I would find my way around and back to where I had entered. Apparently there are over...

This sure was a great experience, we arrived down one floor from our motel and started on our adventure of the Underground City. I would like to have a bit more signs directing in which directions you should go, for your needs. It is convenient, as you don't have to go outside, many shops, fast foods, etc
Took my wife there so that she could understand where people go when the weather gets really cold. There were so many cool shops and restaurants that it kept us occupied for hours.
Even with a map, the signage is small and it's easy to get frustrated and lost! Next time I'll freeze my butt off....

The Underground City sounds so cool... 1. It's not a City... 2. It's not Underground... and 3. It's a waste of time. All it is are a series of underground tunnels, connected to the subway, that open out into a mall with boutiques. The tunnels are very cold, same temperature as the outside, and they are extremely horrible to navigate....
The 3 big shopping malls are connected and it's extremely convenient for customers. They have various choice for food , clothing and accessories

Underground City has a large variety of stores.However, the quality of those stores is pretty low. While the concept of an underground might sound great, if you are looking for a great shopping experience, look elsewhere.

I may have missed something, but if I didn't, all it is is an underground tunnel to get from one side of town to a mall on the other side of town. Maybe if it was pouring rain or a snow storm, otherwise big deal.?
Somehow I thought the underground city would be more than a glorified series of shopping malls. I was wrong. Unless you love mall shopping, skip this. It's nothing to be excited about, truly.

This is an interesting concept to link the city through a series of tunnels that flow under buildings. Good for a cold day, but I thought it was going to be more vibrant with more things to see in the different tunnels. Also, it leaves you with a weird feeling because you can walk great distances but have no visual...

This was the most frustrating part of my Montreal experience. Not only was it difficult to find an entrance, but everyone we asked about it were giving completely different directions. Of which none helped. I've never been lost trying to get in somewhere. We walked for 1h30 and got no where.

What a great place to go when it's raining or cold. There are so many restaurants and cafes that you will find what you want. The main train station comes into the underground city. There are so many retail shops as well that should satisfy any shopper.
A nice cozy place to go when it is freezing outside. It is linked to the metro, which makes it very convenient and has all the necessary shops and outlets.

WOWWWWWW!!!!!! This vibrantly alive city beneath Magical Montreal! far exceeded our expectations. enter the Underground across the street from the Museum of Contemporary Art. The Hyatt Hotel is above this entrance. Delicious affordable restaurants, best Parisian Bakery in town, a dazzling night water and light show , safe, warm eclectic environment. we enjoyed a few hours of leisure strolling with...
This is a very interesting place. Lots and lots of shopping and different types of foods -- from fast food to fairly decent dining places.

I'll give kudos to the Canadians - this is a super idea! Cold and snowy outside? For months? Fine - let's go underground! What an engineering achievement - I can't begin to wrap my head around how they did all of this.You can wander for hours under the city in complete comfort no matter what the weather. Want to...

The strength of the US dollar to Canadian is FABULOUS for shopping! Rather than worrying about conversion rates, it's easy to use your US credit cards or debit cards and let them do the conversion work for you. Our bank exchange rate prior to leaving was $1.25 Canadian to $1 US, when the credit cards / bank cards converted our...

Spent several hours wandering le passage on a Sunday afternoon. It's pretty quiet and there are long stretches without any shops. It's also pretty windy back and forth. Assume it will take 2x as long as walking on the surface.
Montreal has a great underground shopping area, waoh lucky them. The metro get you there, no need of heavy winter boots or coats

We were in Montreal a very limited amount of time as we were heading to Quebec City. We were in Montreal in 1988. The underground mall is huge with quite a few stores and some places to eat. Parts of the mall were pretty crowded, while other parts were empty. When we were walking around, their was a huge display...

The underground city is not an urban myth. It does indeed exist, but don’t expect to find any signs like ” underground city this way”. Look for “RESO” written in small letters on obscure doors around downtown. Open the door and be consumed by the labyrinth for the next few hours, or until you stumble upon an exit. Not that...

Huge underground system connecting swathes of Montreal. Not very well signposted or easy to navigate for non-locals. Interesting in summer but I presume it's vital in winter to escape the freezing conditions.
This was a bit of a disappointment to us as the underground was little more than a second rate underground shopping mall with a food court, and a way to walk underground in inclement weather.

If you plan on visiting this place be prepared to walk, it goes on for miles. All the main street entrances are marked by a 'RESO Sign'. 'Via Rail' is located underground beside a large food court. The food choices are decent but the same as you would find above ground. You can access the 'Eaton Centre Shopping Mall' without...

Visited Montreal in March 2009 and came upon the underground shopping from my hotel which connected to underground Montreal. Really nice to get out of the windy, cold weather of winter. Shops and restaurants throughout the tunnels. I was happy to see the Bay as most of the shops weren't great in quality.
Given that this place is huge and convoluted, I'd expect there to be a detailed map of the underground city. It was very overwhelming to navigate.

We visited Montreal for Christmas. It was cold and some days were snowy and wet. Our hotel was very close to an entrance to the Underground City. It was nice to be able to walk around without freezing, getting our feet wet or slipping on icy pavement.

The underground city is a collection of malls connected by walkways and escalators that allow people to get around the center of the city without having to brace the winter cold. The stores and restaurants are nothing special. You see the same stores everywhere. However, it is a very nice way to get around the city when it is freezing...

We had to go to the "underground city" because the rental car company was there. The only reason I give it 1 star is because we had breakfast and it was decent and the service at the restaurant was very good.Do not invest a minute of your visit there, unless you need to take a train (station and subway...

It's a great place to get out of the wind and the snow for awhile. You can get lost as there are areas with little to no activity and other areas that are bustling. Hard to find the entrances as there are reportedly about 100, but we weren't looking that hard.

It's just an underground mall. Yes, it's an easy way to traverse the city when it's cold, but I don't understand all the attention this place gets. At the end of the day, it's just a mall. I wouldn't go out of your way to see this. If your hotel happens to be part of it as ours was, then...

There are miles, as in over 4 miles of underground shopping, restaurants, and activities for you to enjoy. I go to the fabulous city of Montreal 3 or 4 times every year. Been there in every season, every day of the week, over major holidays, etc. and have spent hours having fun finding all the different ways to get where...

underground city is a smart idea for the cold weather city. the wind and snow is heavy in Montreal, people cannot stand for the cold weather. but the underground city connected all the buildings and subway station. it is very large and convenient.

We were dodging raindrops all day during our visit, but when the skies opened up we headed underground to look for a Metro Station. Little did we know that we would end up wandering the Underground City for hours. This place must be a god-send during those cold, blustery Canadian winters.

Interconnecting pathways to various buildings, and concourse shopping areas, the main one would be the Eaton Centre and if you go up to the street level you are on Ste Catherine. You pass through Gare Centrale (train station), and various Metro (subway) stations. Lots of food courts and dome really nice bakery shops.

I came to Montreal more than 30 years ago and when I heard tourists asking about the underground Montreal, I had no idea what they were talking about. For Montrealers, this is just shopping and instead of being on a street, it is at metro level. I now understand that other cities around the world may not have that. LOL...

Once we actually found it, the underground wasn't what i was expected. I was expecting a shopping mecca. Instead we got just a half shopping mall spread out over a larger area.You'll find most of what you're looking for, but as far as specialty shopping is concerned you'll be dissapointed.Not much more to say.
It was freezing rain when we went to the UC, and it was a nice reprieve. It's pretty much a mall underground with some above-ground spots. The Lindt chocolate shop makes amazing hot chocolate!

This is really misleading and we had a hard time finding "it" because it's really a series of tunnels under the downtown area. Locals didn't understand when we asked about "city" but they recognized the series of tunnels. The actual city part is really a mall, but you can walk east to west a long way without a coat. Helpful...

We went here on one of the coldest days in December 2016 and the temperature was around 71 to 75 degrees in this shopping and dinning wonder.The underground has many eating and shopping locations. It also has goods and services like cellular and cable service, Bell Canada and direct access to many other connected centers spanning Montreal.When I...

My wife and I were in Montreal in September for a couples shopping trip. wow I have heard much about the underground city and the shopping but it is so much more impressive then any stories. There is every type of store you can imagine. We had a great time, would recommend this trip to anybody that can make it....

You can find anything in this underground shopping paradise. High end and low end, it has it all. Get your nails done, eat at Burger King and then shop in the high end shops. All while staying warm. Easy on and off Metro stop.

It was freezing during our trip and we needed to get some souvenirs for family. The underground city was a connection of stores, services, food locations etc - it suited its purpose for sure during a crazy cold day.

This venue is not the American Shopping Mall that you might think it is after reading the website. This venue is some interconnected, but not associated, shopping areas in office buildings and hotels. Only a few of the locations, like the Eaton Centre, are actual shopping malls.Do not think that you're going to enjoy walking the length of this...

The underground city is amazing - you can spend days walking and shopping there. Wear your most comfortable shoes as it is a large series of interconnected malls, some malls with 4 levels and 80-100 stores. Stores range from high end department stores and jewelry stores to dollar stores - and almost everything in between.What always amazes me is...

Perhaps this has some attraction if you like shopping, but otherwise I cannot see the point. Sure, it is a way to escape the winter cold, but you can shop anywhere and it is not as if the shops are unique in any way.

We visited while in town for a few days. It's a very interesting place, but it is confusing. You have to have a map, and ask one of the information people to even figure out how to get to the place, much less get around once you get there. It is a labyrinth without parallel. A lot of interesting stores...

Lots of shops, restaurants, and bustling with people. This underground connection of shopping malls is an excellent way to stay warm while you shop during winter. The shops all had sales and we were able to get to the Place de Ville Marie Observatory without walking along the windy streets. Quite an interesting concept.
Limited selection but on cold Montreal days it is sometimes nice to be inside out of the cold. Can't get very far in this underground city though.

My pre-conceived notion was that the underground city would be narrow hallways full of brand name stores. WRONG!This network of halls and atria is beautifully lit, has mostly local stores ... lots of cafés, a stores that supply everyday needs as wells as mid and higher priced stores. Lots of activities for families.We had fun navigating this warren...

The ideal place for shopping all underground! miles and miles of malls, restaurants , cinema, theaters, the works!You can spend entire days without setting foot outside! It is the best when it is minus 20 outside or sweltering in mid-july!
Huge amount of shops, great variety. Would have preferred better quality restaurants. The fast food was not bad, ut a few more upmarket ones would add value to the mall

Under the city you find restaurants, shops of every kind. Forget about the weather and just shop ,shop and shop some more. Every brand imaginable is present. If you jst want to walk around do so...always busy .

Montreals underground city, it is a huge sprawling interconnected series of malls passages lined with small stores, it twists and turns, inter connects with the metro, it can occupy several vertical level both below and above ground including the principal stores and some hotels. For a visitor it can be very confusing to navigate, you loose all sense of direction...

I visited in the Summer, when the weather was beautiful outside. If the weather is pretty outside, you need to take advantage of the sun, however if it is raining or snowing then the Underground City is the perfect destination. It is easily accessible via the subway. There are lots of stores and restaurants all underground, be careful it's so...
More like a mall. We could not find anything worth calling an underground city. It's mostly several malls connecting - that way you can walk for miles and miles in a warm place ifIt's rainy or cold.

the underground is a collection of your normal mall stores situated in downtown Montreal. the nice thing is that when the weather is bad you can shop till you drop as everything is connected underground.
Great place to dodge the weather but expect to get lost and make sure to find a map, it’s a huge complex underground filled with shops and food.

You might need a map to get around here, especially if you are looking for something in particular. Handy way to get around town if you want to avoid cold or rain. The shops had hefty price tags so we didn't buy a thing. Food courts have free wi-fi.

With over 30 kms of tunnels, you could seriously become a mole person, and with the extremes of HOT humid summers and bitterly cold winter winds one can see why this refuge was developed. You can find everything here from shopping malls, to restaurants, to hotels & the metro connects it all ! Easy to get turned around but very...

Montreal has an extensive network of tunnels that allow you to get around without braving the elements on the street. Be forewarned, though: It's pretty easy to get disoriented. Hesitation and puzzled looks draw help quickly from even lunchtime workers racing back to the office.

The underground city really comes into its own when the winter grips the city but we enjoyed it as a respite from the summer heat. There is virtually every kind of shop, service and restaurant down here and it is a great place to explore, covering a huge area. Just keep your wits about you and look a the signs...
Basically an underground mall. There are many entrances/exits so it can be confusing trying to make sure you know where you are coming out.
This is a wonderful experience, but be prepared to be lost in the various underground passageways ....at least once !
Be aventurous and discover how to travel through this spree.BARBIE Exposition, dvd, WINNERS, ETC.Fun
It is very cool that Montreal offers that and you can move around totally dry even in rainy days. It muight be boring for some people but also very different
I guess if you are looking to avoid the outdoors, this is a good place to visit - once you find it. I found the signage to be poor (I know French) and confusing.
An area of several city blocks accesible by metro as well as by walking. Many stores and restaurants to choose from.
This underground tunnel system connects a huge underground shopping center with the metro stations. Shop untill you drop.

Read about this location in the travel magazines, but not that easy to locate from the street level. Best location to enter was through McGill Metro station which leads into the heart of the underground city and a multi-level mall. It is reminiscent of the Tokyo train stations with lots of shops and restaurants. It is really handy on those...
Miles of shops and places to eat. Clean, bright, safe. It was great on a very rainy day. Enter at the Eaton Center ( Le Centre Eaton) on rue Ste-Catherine.
There is a lot to do in the underground, year round. But I prefer to use it in winter when it is very cold. During summer I only come in when necessary, to check out certainly shops.
Grab a map! Finding your way out can be hard, but being lost is well worth it. Tons of shops and eateries to explore. Lots of reasonably priced souvenir stores as well.

It took us a while to figure it out, but once we did, we really enjoyed the underground mall - especially as it was pouring outside. It was nice to get around with the Metro without getting our feet wet!

If you have to visit Montreal in the wintertime, and the weather is somewhat inclement, take the time to visit our underground city. You can walk for miles and find all the services you can hope for, from fine food, fast food, shopping of all types, theatre, etc. etc. Office workers can leave from there garages, park indoors, and return...
In town for the weekend and as luck had it, it rained all Saturday. My friend took my wife, daughter and I to the Underground City. We had a nice dry walk around and my wife got to do some shopping.
I found the Underground City fine, but it was just a "mall" with a food court. It was raining outside so it ended up being a good place to retreat to.

We entered the complex after a bus tour we took and had planned to wander through to get to our hotel which has an entrance/exit right around the corner. WE got lost and could not figure out how to get there despite having a map. We finally exited and made our way home via the streets. I will say the...

column4: It's a great idea for a very cold winter city and a challenge of construction completed. But basically is a web of paths that connects important buildings to the life of downtown and also provides shopping stores to entertain you indoors.

We were in town during horrible weather. We weren't shopping but it was still cool to see all of the underground "malls". There are many. Least impressive was Eaton Center. The Cours Mont-Royal underground shopping was lovely. It was great being able to say in at a hotel (Le Westin) that goes right into the tunnels. Everything is available there....

Built to combat the deep snow experienced by Montreal, this is a way of walking around the city without going outside. I'm sure for locals it is brillant but is somewhat confusing for the visitor. My advice is to experience it rather than try to get somewhere.

The Montreal underground city is fun to visit as it shows you how Montrealers get around during hot summer days and cold winter days. There is lots of shopping to do and even movie theaters but the fun part is to use the passageways to make it to other buildings downtown and the exiting onto the street and seeing where...
When inside a modern shopping mall, you could be in any city. Their all the same, so unless its havy rain or so hot you will escape underground, skip it.

Since it has rained for 2 days, we have enjoyed shopping & dining in this nice underground city. There are a large variety of shops & there are food count areas to enjoy a meal or just a coffee.We found this very nice to stay out of the rain.
A city under a city. Talked to a lovely information lady and she said some People never see the light of day during the winter. It has literally everything you could want.
If you like shopping come here...otherwise not worth the visit. Can be confusing to get around and if you bring a stroller be prepared to carry it up and down stairs at times.
We stopped at the Underground City on a tour of Montreal. The size of the shopping mall is very large, and the windows were decorated so beautifully.
Like being in a science fiction movie..Or after Nuclear age where the SUN would burn your skin after fossil fuel Eara

The underground city is a tour de force of urban planning. Especially for a city like Montreal, where the winters are hard and the summers can be hot. Given the multiple levels that intersect and the multiple metro stops that are involved, it is much more than a mall. There are places where the use of space is breathtaking, and...
Took a long time to find!When it was found I LOVED it. Special but enjoyable arrangement of a shopping mall.There you can buy everything from, food to flowers - and of course clothes.

We were enthralled by the idea of an Underground City as we thought it was only a Mall. It is easy to get lost in the maze of tunnels, escalators, ect. in this five story city. And, yes, it is a city.On our tour we learned that the Underground City was built because of Montreal's hard winters. One can...
It is a good place to escape the heat. Somewhat novel but beyond this not spectacular. I could see how this would be especially valuable in Winter, however.

While we were there outside the snowy season, it was really curious to imagine how the city functions during Winter. I lived in several cities in Western Canada (none with an underground city) and I know how cold and inconvenient Winter can be. For that reason, seeing how Montreal deals with it was particularly interesting. The underground city is actually...
Came upon this by accident after exploring old Montreal. Found a nice little spot for pastries near the food court. Didn't do much shopping but would go back to do some shopping
Lots of shopping if you are into that. Didn't see anything that unique. I guess its a good place to go in bad weather.

It rained the Saturday we were there. Went to the under ground city and forgot all about it browsing all the stores etc to be found. Had a bit of a time finding the connections to the other malls but still enjoyed it.
This is a mall that is underground. Unless you are a mall enthusiast, you may want to skip this and spend your time doing something else.

Large shopping areas connected by tunnels and direct access to the metro - lots of different stores, something for everyone. Make sure you look at a map and know the next bldg to connect to. It's very large and easy to go off in the wrong direction! Great for those rainy days - you don't even need to go outside!
It was a unique experience, but I didn't find anything to buy. I returned at 5pm on a Monday and the mall was closed. So please go early.

So when I heard "Underground City", I suppose I pictured Montreal architecture of a bygone era preserved for my viewing pleasure with maybe some local shops and cafes. That is NOT the reality. It's just a giant mall with all the same fancy and not so fancy stores you can find at most urban malls in the states.I'm sure...

The Montreal underground is a great place to shop , eat , connect or just escape from the sometimes less agreeable weather outside . Extensive if you are really willing to discover its full range . The best & top brand names are no longer as present in Montreal as they used to be , but you can still find...

Its great to go underground in Montreal you can from one mall to another without seeing daylight or any inclement weather the only problem is its quite dis-orientating until you get used to it so take a city map.

Unlike Toronto this underground city is confusing for the tourists. We followed a RES sign through a government building only to find the escalator closed. We asked someone where to go and they directed use to another entrance but this door was locked!Later we saw a guided tour heading off down another RES pathway so we followed. But all...
The biggest underground city is here! Very nice place to go take a walk by any weather. Connected directly at the Metro network and to the downtown. Enjoyable all the year long.
We saw just a small part of this vast underground system, which complete with underground stations, is amazing. Interesting to see where everyone goes when the "extremely cold weather strikes.
Nice place, all sorts of stores. Just watch your purse. If you have trouble walking and require a walker you have to really look for a elevator. But they do assist you.
The montreal underground city is also a must - see attraction ! I recommend a map not to get lost because it is huge!
What a mindblowing experience to be able to walk from shopping mall to shopping mall underground-awesome and highly recommended
I needed a pharmacy and easily found one there. The fountain was fun to watch shoot the water in the air.

This is a blue print for cities with snow. I think if you know it properly you wouldn't have to come out until the spring!Restaurants, lounge ares, stores of every kind. Sure wish we had this when I lived in Chicago!

I was astonished at this incredible network located underneath the streets of Montreal. The network is particularly useful during Montreal's long winters. You can access the Underground city from many metro stations. I enjoyed it a lot! My impressions: I found everything clean and I felt secure walking around.If you want to eat something, you will find many fast...
A full under ground shopping area, if it is hot or cold depending on the season, you can go underground and do everything from shopping to dining and all in comfort

So my husband and I walked around for almost an hour before we could find this underground shopping centre. We were down in the subway trying to get directions and no one we talked to knew how to get there. We finally found it by accident when we were walking back to our hotel. You would think everyone would know...
You can shop come rain, storm, or snow in this underground mall. Many shops to choose from and you never need to step outside!

Whoever said such a city existed would be a liar anywhere in the world, except in Montreal. Great network of stores, restaurants, metro station leading to all the major universities, hotels, building, spreading over kilometers.Incredible during the summer. Can't wait to experience it in the winter when it is freezing cold outside and every one finds all they need...

We had a very hard time finding underground city. We went to many metro stations and walked all around trying to find it. We finally found that it is easily accessed if you go to peel metro station. There is an entrance in the station and it is easy to find from there. There are many great shops and this...
I went here on a windy day. It was different to be able to come down off the street, and duck into a place filled with so many shops and places to explore.
This is not your typical underground mall. You can spend days down here shopping for most anything and connecting with most forms of transportation. A lot of fun and worth a few hours shopping
If you love shopping and/or eating, this is the place to go in Montreal. Loads of shops selling just about everything and loads of food outlets and shops to please everybody's tastes.

city underground. thats what it feels like, everything you need is all inside. shops,, foodcourts, train stations, supermarket, souvenirs . when outside temperature below 5degrees. inside the mall is super warm and cosy. entrance is every corner, and you would find yourself endup in a different streets. surrounded with heritage and old building, feels like we in europe for a...
If you need to shop, check it out. Nothing very special about it and barely as nice as the average USA mall. Food court was very dimly lit. Hard to find entrances so ask someone.
It looks like one city under another one. You can find there cinema theaters, shops, barber salons,restaurants and many others interesting places.

Everything connected together and easily accessible by metro, has everything that you need! Available and accessible.It's the best and the greatest when it comes tomall shopping and connects to the cinema too!
Great unique adventure awaits! countless shops, cafes and restaurants to be discovered....amazing vibe...all connected by underground passageways. Perfect for winter visits!!
For those w ho want to shop till they drop this underground will suit.Great for all weather conditions.Follow the signs as a visitor

So we have heard a lot of the underground city life of Montreal in winter. Well it is probably best to explore it... in winter... A late summer visit was kind of pointless. Except to say that now we know where it is. The concept though is interesting. ..

Several malls connected to each other but not lots of brands, clean place for tits bits shopping.. One can go there just to roam and check how so many malls are connected to each other but in basement level in one big part it was all vacant all shops were I guess permanently closed
The "Underground City" was amazing. The maze that connects the levels of stores and cafes was brilliant.
Well worth a trip, nit just for the excellent shopping but also to appreciate the architecture and how it inter-connects, introducing, light, water and space
There was an entrance just a few blocks from our hotel. We had to go in and out of different sections to find another. There had to be a way to stay underground but we could not find a map anywhere.
It has surely changed since I was there last. It was like being in a shopping mall Nothing spectacular

this is an underground mall that stretches for miles. I was surprised that I recognized most of the stores from the U.S. There are several food courts to appease your appetite. While some of them were run of the mill, many appeared to be one of a kind eateries, and they cooked your food when you ordered it, not exactly...

Did not enjoy this underground at all. It was a very limited area and seemed to consist of upscale shops only. wasted my time going there. They do have a fantastic food court with a variety of foods to choose from.

After reviewing St. Catherine street I had no choice but review this one also. Basically the same stuff as St. Catherine street, but underground, which comes very handy in long cold winters.It allows you to drive from your hotel or home in a T shirt and walk almost whole Montreal downtown underground with full access to shopping and restaurants....
